elements.content: Eight new zinc diphosphonates, [NaZn(O3P(CH2)2PO3H)] (1), [K2Zn2(HO3P(CH2)2PO3H)(O3P(CH2)2PO3)] (2), [(NH4)(H3N(CH2)2NH3)0.5Zn3(O3P(CH2)2PO3)2] (3), [(NH4)2Zn3(O3P(CH2)3PO3)2] (4), [(H3N(CH2)4NH3)0.5Zn(O3P(CH2)3PO3H)] (5), [KZn(O3P(CH2)4PO3H)] (6), [KZn(HO3P(CH2)4PO3H)(Cl)] (7), and [NH4Zn(O3P(CH2)4PO3H)] (8), have been successfully synthesized under mixed solvothermal conditions and characterized by X-ray single-crystal diffraction together with elemental analysis, infrared spectroscopy, thermogravimetric analysis, and powder X-ray diffraction. In 1 and 2, 1,2-ethylenediphosphonate groups combine cations (Na+, K+) and Zn−O−P layers into 3D frameworks, while in 3 and 4, ethylene and propylene groups are enclosed in novel 3D Zn−O−P frameworks, respectively, which possess 8-membered ring (8MR) and 12MR channels. In 5 − 8, Zn−O−P infinite chains are pillared by 1,3-propylene- and 1,4-butylenediphosphonate groups into hybrid layers. It is interesting that in 7 K−Cl lamellae link the Zn−O−P hybrid layer to form a 3D sandwichlike framework. If 1 is synthesized with commercial fluorescent whitener (disodium 4,4‘-bis(2-sulfonatostyryl)biphenyl) in the initial reaction mixture, it exhibits bright purple-blue luminescence with a short lifetime. Photoluminescent properties of 4 and 8 are also discussed.

elements.content: Varying the lengths of the alkylenediphosphonic acids (H2O3P(CH2) n PO3H2, n = 2−4) and the cations (including Na+, K+, NH4 +, H3N(CH2)2NH3 2+, and H3N(CH2)4NH3 2+), eight new zinc diphosphonates have been successfully synthesized under mixed solvothermal conditions and characterized with X-ray single-crystal diffraction as well as elemental analysis, infrared spectroscopy, thermogravimetric analysis, X-ray diffraction, and photoluminescent properties. These solids possess interesting Zn−O−P chains, layers, and 3D frameworks.

elements.content: At present the design and construction of new functional solids based on metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) has been extensively studied. This is not only due to their structural diversities but also for their potential or practical application in the area of catalysis, gas storage, enantioselective separation, nonlinear optics, and so on. In this realm an encouraging research direction is to synthesize metal phosphonates, which represent a new class of hybrid materials exhibiting intriguing structures and properties. After being pioneered by Clearfield, metal phosphonates have been exploited as follows. Layered metal monophosphonates (M/RPO3) are very useful in the area of intercalation chemistry. Metal diphosphonates (M/O3PRPO3) are important in preparing meso/microporous materials because of their 3D pillared open frameworks, which could be fine-tuned via modifying the lengths and shapes of the organic units. Enantiopure organodiphosphonic acids are introduced as asymmetric building bridges to obtain homochiral porous materials for potential applications in enantioselective processes. Multifunctional phosphonic acids containing −NH2, −OH, and −COOH sub functional groups and providing many coordination modes have been used as bridging ligands to synthesize many interesting solids, such as [Zn3(O3PCH2COO)2(O3PCH2COOH)(NH3CH2CH2NH3)(BTC)] (BTC = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid) with 24-ring channels, homochiral Zn2[(S)-O3PCH2NHC4H7CO2]2 with helical channels, M x [Fe(O2CCH2)2NCH2PO3]6·nH2O (M = Na, K, Rb) with a maple leaf lattice, nickel N,N‘-piperazinebis(methylenephosphonate) possessing large pores greater than ca. 10 Å in free diameter, and 3D open-framework (NH4)Zn[O3PCH(OH)CO2] with nonlinear optical activity and high thermal stability. Second ligands such as 1,10-phenanthroline, 2,2‘-bipyridine, 4,4‘-bipyridine, and tetra-2-pyridylpyrazine are introduced into metal phosphonates to synthesize many novel hybrid materials with polynuclear clusters, chains, layers, and 3D open frameworks. Phosphonate groups bridge M x O y (M = Mo, W, and V) polyoxoanion building blocks into cages, chains, layers, and 3D inorganic−organic hybrid molecular sieves with extralarge cages. Nevertheless, it is still challenging to design and rationally synthesize metal phosphonates with unique structures and functions. One of the obstacles is the difficulty of growing sizable single crystals due to their low solubility, which prevents us from understanding accurate structures from X-ray single-crystal diffraction. Recently, under mixed solvothermal conditions we successfully obtained high-quality single crystals of a sodium zinc 1,4-butylenediphosphonate. The crystal size reached several millimeters. X-ray single-crystal diffraction reveals that it possesses a polar pillarlike open framework capturing Na+ cations within an 8-membered ring (8MR) in the Zn−O−P layer. Further, bright luminescent zinc diphosphonates with 12MR channels have also been designed and mix-solvothermally synthesized by introducing a fluorescent guest as the structure-directing agent (SDA). It is obvious that the mix-solvothermal method is a powerful way to grow suitable single crystals of metal phosphonates. A series of experiments have been performed to investigate the effect of cations and the lengths of phosphonic acids on the structures of metal phosphonates. Herein, we describe the mix-solvothermal syntheses, characterization, and properties of eight new zinc alkylenediphosphonates, [NaZn(O3P(CH2)2PO3H)] (1), [K2Zn2(HO3P(CH2)2PO3H)(O3P(CH2)2PO3)] (2), [(NH4)(H3N(CH2)2NH3)0.5Zn3(O3P(CH2)2PO3)2] (3), [(NH4)2Zn3(O3P(CH2)3PO3)2] (4), [(H3N(CH2)4NH3)0.5Zn(O3P(CH2)3PO3H)] (5), [KZn(O3P(CH2)4PO3H)] (6), [KZn(HO3P(CH2)4PO3H)(Cl)] (7), and [NH4Zn(O3P(CH2)4 PO3H)] (8).
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

At present the design and construction of new functional solids based on metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) has been extensively studied. This is not only due to their structural diversities but also for their potential or practical application in the area of catalysis, gas storage, enantioselective separation, nonlinear optics, and so on. In this realm an encouraging research direction is to synthesize metal phosphonates, which represent a new class of hybrid materials exhibiting intriguing structures and properties. After being pioneered by Clearfield, metal phosphonates have been exploited as follows. Layered metal monophosphonates (M/RPO3) are very useful in the area of intercalation chemistry. Metal diphosphonates (M/O3PRPO3) are important in preparing meso/microporous materials because of their 3D pillared open frameworks, which could be fine-tuned via modifying the lengths and shapes of the organic units. Enantiopure organodiphosphonic acids are introduced as asymmetric building bridges to obtain homochiral porous materials for potential applications in enantioselective processes. Multifunctional phosphonic acids containing -NH2, -OH, and -COOH sub functional groups and providing many coordination modes have been used as bridging ligands to synthesize many interesting solids, such as [Zn3(O3PCH2COO)2(O3PCH2COOH)(NH3CH2CH2NH3)(BTC)] (BTC = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid) with 24-ring channels, homochiral Zn2[(S)-O3PCH2NHC4H7CO2]2 with helical channels, M x [Fe(O2CCH2)2NCH2PO3]6⋅nH2O (M = Na, K, Rb) with a maple leaf lattice, nickel N,N‘-piperazinebis(methylenephosphonate) possessing large pores greater than ca. 10 Å in free diameter, and 3D open-framework (NH4)Zn[O3PCH(OH)CO2] with nonlinear optical activity and high thermal stability. Second ligands such as 1,10-phenanthroline, 2,2‘-bipyridine, 4,4‘-bipyridine, and tetra-2-pyridylpyrazine are introduced into metal phosphonates to synthesize many novel hybrid materials with polynuclear clusters, chains, layers, and 3D open frameworks. Phosphonate groups bridge M x O y  (M = Mo, W, and V) polyoxoanion building blocks into cages, chains, layers, and 3D inorganic-organic hybrid molecular sieves with extralarge cages. Nevertheless, it is still challenging to design and rationally synthesize metal phosphonates with unique structures and functions. One of the obstacles is the difficulty of growing sizable single crystals due to their low solubility, which prevents us from understanding accurate structures from X-ray single-crystal diffraction. Recently, under mixed solvothermal conditions we successfully obtained high-quality single crystals of a sodium zinc 1,4-butylenediphosphonate. The crystal size reached several millimeters. X-ray single-crystal diffraction reveals that it possesses a polar pillarlike open framework capturing Na+ cations within an 8-membered ring (8MR) in the Zn-O-P layer. Further, bright luminescent zinc diphosphonates with 12MR channels have also been designed and mix-solvothermally synthesized by introducing a fluorescent guest as the structure-directing agent (SDA). It is obvious that the mix-solvothermal method is a powerful way to grow suitable single crystals of metal phosphonates. A series of experiments have been performed to investigate the effect of cations and the lengths of phosphonic acids on the structures of metal phosphonates. Herein, we describe the mix-solvothermal syntheses, characterization, and properties of eight new zinc alkylenediphosphonates, [NaZn(O3P(CH2)2PO3H)] (1), [K2Zn2(HO3P(CH2)2PO3H)(O3P(CH2)2PO3)] (2), [(NH4)(H3N(CH2)2NH3)0.5Zn3(O3P(CH2)2PO3)2] (3), [(NH4)2Zn3(O3P(CH2)3PO3)2] (4), [(H3N(CH2)4NH3)0.5Zn(O3P(CH2)3PO3H)] (5), [KZn(O3P(CH2)4PO3H)] (6), [KZn(HO3P(CH2)4PO3H)(Cl)] (7), and [NH4Zn(O3P(CH2)4 PO3H)] (8).

elements.content: General Procedures. H2O3P(CH2) n PO3H2 (n = 2−4) were prepared according to a previously reported method. Other chemicals with reagent-grade quality were purchased from commercial sources without purification. These complexes were synthesized in 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessels under autogenous pressure with a filling capacity of ∼40%. The reactants were stirred homogeneously before heating. Elemental analysis was carried out with a Vario EL III element analyzer. Infrared spectra were obtained on a Nicolet Magna 750 FT-IR spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a NETZSCH STA 449C unit under nitrogen gas at heating rates of 10 °C·min-1 (for 1, 2, 4, 5, and 8) and 15 °C·min-1 (for 3, 6, and 7) from room temperature to 800 °C. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were acquired on a DMAX-2500 diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation in an ambient environment. The fluorescent properties of solids 1b, 4, and 8 were determined with an FLS920 instrument at room temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 General Procedures. H2O3P(CH2) n PO3H2 (n = 2-4) were prepared according to a previously reported method. Other chemicals with reagent-grade quality were purchased from commercial sources without purification. These complexes were synthesized in 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessels under autogenous pressure with a filling capacity of ~40%. The reactants were stirred homogeneously before heating.  Elemental analysis was carried out with a Vario EL III element analyzer. Infrared spectra were obtained on a Nicolet Magna 750 FT-IR spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a NETZSCH STA 449C unit under nitrogen gas at heating rates of 10 °C⋅min-1 (for 1, 2, 4, 5, and 8) and 15 °C⋅min-1 (for 3, 6, and 7) from room temperature to 800 °C. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were acquired on a DMAX-2500 diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation in an ambient environment. The fluorescent properties of solids 1b, 4, and 8 were determined with an FLS920 instrument at room temperature.

Synthesis of [NaZn(O 3 P(CH 2 ) 2 PO 3 H)] (1). A mixture of Zn(CH3COO)2·2H2O (0.1069 g, 0.4870 mmol), H2O3P(CH2)2PO3H2 (0.0583 g, 0.307 mmol), NaCl (1.0254 g, 17.546 mmol), n-butyric acid (8.0 mL, 86 mmol), and H2O (2.0 mL, 111 mmol) was heated at 180 °C for 164 h. After the mixture was allowed to cool slowly to ambient temperature, colorless needle-shaped crystals were obtained. The final pH of the solution was 1.05. The crystals were filtered, washed with distilled water, and dried at ambient temperature. The pattern of powder XRD was in agreement with that simulated from single-crystal X-ray data, which indicated a homogeneous phase. The yield was about 12% (0.0101 g) based on H2O3P(CH2)2PO3H2. Anal. Calcd for C2H5O6P2NaZn (1):  C, 8.72; H, 1.83. Found:  C, 8.81; H, 2.23. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1):  3462m, 2960w (νC - H), 2924m (νC - H), 2911w (νC - H), 2866w (νC - H), 2401w, 2054w, 1618m, 1417m (δC - H), 1201s (νP  O), 1157s (νP - O), 1109vs (νP - O), 1076vs (νP - O), 1051s (νP - O), 1005vs (νP - O), 924s, 885w, 804m, 758m, 717m, 563m, 528m, 490m, 471m. In addition, 1 can also be obtained with commercial fluorescent whitener (disodium 4,4‘-bis(2-sulfonatostyryl)biphenyl) in the initial mixture as follows. A mixture of Zn(CH3COO)2·2H2O (0.1115 g, 0.5080 mmol), H2O3P(CH2)2PO3H2 (0.0577 g, 0.304 mmol), NaCl (1.1827 g, 20.238 mmol), disodium 4,4‘-bis(2-sulfonatostyryl)biphenyl (0.2798 g, 0.4974 mmol), n-butyric acid (8.0 mL, 86 mmol), and H2O (2.0 mL, 111 mmol) was heated at 160 °C for 144 h. After the mixture was allowed to cool slowly to ambient temperature, blue needle-shaped crystals (denoted as 1b) were obtained. The final pH of the solution was 2.12. The crystals were filtered, washed with distilled water, and dried at ambient temperature. After the blue needle-shaped crystals were ground into a white powder, the powder XRD pattern was essentially in agreement with that simulated from X-ray single-crystal data. The IR spectrum of 1b is also in accord with that of 1.

Synthesis of [K 2 Zn 2 (HO 3 P(CH 2 ) 2 PO 3 H)(O 3 P(CH 2 ) 2 PO 3 )] (2). A mixture of Zn(CH3COO)2·2H2O (0.1031 g, 0.4697 mmol), H2O3P(CH2)2PO3H2 (0.0520 g, 0.274 mmol), KCl (0.9877 g, 13.37 mmol), n-butyric acid (8.0 mL, 86 mmol), and H2O (2.0 mL, 111 mmol) was heated at 180 °C for 48 h. After the mixture was allowed to cool slowly to ambient temperature, colorless prismatic crystals were obtained. The final pH of the solution was 2.13. The crystals were filtered, washed with distilled water, and dried at ambient temperature. The pattern of powder XRD matched that simulated from single-crystal X-ray data, which indicated a homogeneous phase. The yield was about 46% (0.0368 g) based on H2O3PCH2CH2PO3H2. Anal. Calcd for C4H10K2O12P4Zn2 (2):  C, 8.28; H, 1.74. Found:  C, 8.21; H, 1.98. Synthesis of [(NH 4 )(H 3 N(CH 2 ) 2 NH 3 ) 0.5 Zn 3 (O 3 P(CH 2 ) 2 PO 3 ) 2 ] (3). A mixture of Zn(CH3COO)2·2H2O (0.1052 g, 0.4793 mmol), CH5N3·HCl (0.6202 g, 6.492 mmol), H2N(CH2)4NH2·2HCl (0.3267 g, 1.866 mmol), (CH3)4NBr (0.1738 g, 1.128 mmol), HN(CH2CH2NH2)3·4HCl (0.4954 g, 1.690 mmol), H2O3P(CH2)2PO3H2 (0.1046 g, 0.5504 mmol), NaF (0.2203 g, 5.246 mmol), n-butyric acid (2.0 mL, 22 mmol), and H2O (8.0 mL, 444 mmol) was heated at 180 °C for 96 h. After the mixture was allowed to cool slowly to ambient temperature, colorless prismatic crystals were obtained. The final pH of the solution was about 5.5. The crystals were filtered, washed with distilled water, and dried at ambient temperature. The yield was about 83% (0.0821 g) based on Zn(CH3COO)2·2H2O. Anal. Calcd for C6H20N2O12P4Zn3 (3):  C, 9.73; H, 2.78; N, 4.54. Found:  C, 9.77; H, 2.74; N, 4.74. elements.content: X-r ay Crystallography. X-ray data were collected on a Rigaku Mercury CCD/AFC (for 1 and 3 − 8) and a SMART CCD (for 2) diffractometer using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ(Mo Kα) = 0.71073 Å). The data of 1 and 3 − 8 were reduced with CrystalClear v1.3, while the data of 2 were reduced and absorption corrected with SMART and SADABS software, respectively. All structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques on F 2 using SHELXTL-97. All non-hydrogen atoms were treated anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms of 1, 4, 5, 7, and 8 and H2−H9 of 6 were from a difference Fourier map with a fixed isotropic thermal parameter, while other hydrogen atoms were treated geometrically. Furthermore, no attempts were made to locate the hydrogen atoms of NH4 + in 3 and 4 and the hydrogen atoms of H3N(CH2)2NH3 2+ in 3. In addition, the C5 and C6 atoms of H3N(CH2)2NH3 2+ in 3 are in disorder. Crystallographic data for 1 − 8 are summarized in Table , and the selected bond lengths and angles for 1 − 8 are listed in Tables −9. The CCDC deposition numbers are 605451 (for 1), 605452 (for 2), 623358 (for 3), 623359 (for 4), 623360 (for 5), 605454 (for 6), 605455 (for 7), and 623361 (for 8).

elements.content: Synthesis and Characterization. n-Butyric acid and propionic acid are weak acids with higher boiling points than water. Under mixed solvothermal conditions they would provide a relatively stable environment for the growth of high-quality single crystals. Except the cations, 1 and 2 were synthesized with the same conditions, such as the ratio of reactants, reaction temperature, and so on. However, the structure of 1 is different from that of 2, which may be due to the different size of Na(I) and K(I) atoms. Under mixed solvothermal conditions at 180 °C, guanidine hydrochloride (CH5N3·HCl) would hydrolyze and provide NH4 + cation for 3, 4, and 8. HN(CH2CH2NH2)3 4+ would also hydrolyze and provide H3NCH2CH2NH3 2+ cation during the synthesis of 3. In the syntheses of 3, 4, and 8, although H2N(CH2)4NH2·2HCl, (CH3)4NBr, CH5N3·HCl, and 4,4‘-bipyridine are not combined into final products, they may play an important role as SDAs to grow suitable single crystals. In addition, NaF would react with n-butyric acid to produce HF, which can increase the solubility of 3, 4, and 8.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

 Synthesis and Characterization. n-Butyric acid and propionic acid are weak acids with higher boiling points than water. Under mixed solvothermal conditions they would provide a relatively stable environment for the growth of high-quality single crystals. Except the cations, 1 and 2 were synthesized with the same conditions, such as the ratio of reactants, reaction temperature, and so on. However, the structure of 1 is different from that of 2, which may be due to the different size of Na(I) and K(I) atoms. Under mixed solvothermal conditions at 180 °C, guanidine hydrochloride (CH5N3⋅HCl) would hydrolyze and provide NH4 + cation for 3, 4, and 8. HN(CH2CH2NH2)3 4+ would also hydrolyze and provide H3NCH2CH2NH3 2+ cation during the synthesis of 3. In the syntheses of 3, 4, and 8, although H2N(CH2)4NH2⋅2HCl, (CH3)4NBr, CH5N3⋅HCl, and 4,4‘-bipyridine are not combined into final products, they may play an important role as SDAs to grow suitable single crystals. In addition, NaF would react with n-butyric acid to produce HF, which can increase the solubility of 3, 4, and 8.

elements.content: In the synthesis of 7, when the quantity of KCl is reduced by half, the final product consists of a white powder and a few colorless prismatic crystals. The powder XRD patterns of the white powder are different from those of 7. This result indicates the quantity of KCl is important. On the other hand, when an attempt is made to prepare the analogous Br complex by the replacement of KCl with KBr, however, there is no solid in the final mixture. Therefore, some KOH was added to increase the pH, accidentally resulting in 6. However, the structure of 6 is different from that of 7. In addition, although the synthesis conditions of 2 and 7 are almost the same, the structure of 7 is obviously different from that of 2, which is attributed to different lengths of the alkylenediphosphonate groups.

elements.content: The powder XRD patterns of 1 , 2, 6, and 7 are all essentially in agreement with those simulated from X-ray single-crystal data, which indicate the homogeneous phases of the final products (Figures S1−4, Supporting Information (SI)). The PO stretching vibration of the phosphonate group in 1 − 8 appears as a strong single peak around 1200 cm-1, while the P−O stretching vibrations of the phosphonate group in 1 − 8 are observed as a series of medium to strong peaks in the range of 983−1172 cm-1.

elements.content: Structural Descriptions. In 1 − 6 and 8, the Zn(II) atoms are in a distorted [ZnO4] coordination geometry with four oxygen atoms from four different alkylenediphosphonate groups, while it is interesting that in 7 the Zn(II) center is surrounded by one Cl- anion and three phosphonate oxygen donors in a distorted [ZnClO3] coordination geometry. The Zn−O bond lengths fall in the range of 1.911(3)−1.9722(15) Å, and the Zn−O−Zn bond angles lie between 94.4(2)° and 124.59(7)°. [ZnO4] or [ZnClO3] tetrahedrons share corners with [CPO3] tetrahedrons to form different dimensional inorganic Zn−O−P subarchitectures, such as chains, layers, and 3D frameworks.

elements.content: Crystal Structure of [NaZn(O 3 P(CH 2 ) 2 PO 3 H)] (1). The 1,2-ethylenediphosphonate group is in a new μ9:η2:η1:η1:η2:η2:η2 coordination mode and bonds four Zn(II) and five Na(I) atoms through phosphonate oxygen atoms (Figure ). This coordination mode is quite different from μ8:η1:η2:η2:η1:η2:η2 in [Zn(O3PCH2CH2PO3)(H2O)2], as well as μ4:η1:η1:η1:η1 and μ6:η1:η1:η1:η1:η1:η1 in [(C5H14N2)Zn4(HO3PCH2CH2PO3H)(O3PCH2CH2PO3)2]. The Na(I) atom is six-coordinated and possesses a [NaO6] severely distorted octahedral geometry. The six coordinated oxygen atoms are from five different 1,2-ethylenediphosphonate groups. Because the O1a and O3a atoms are from the same 1,2-ethylenediphosphonate group, the bond angle O1a−Na1−O3a is only 55.87(6)°. On one hand, each [ZnO4] tetrahedron contacts three neighboring [NaO6] octahedrons through an edge (O1 and O6d), a corner (O4), and a corner (O5b), resulting in a Na/Zn−O metal oxide layer consisting of 6MRs (Figure S6, SI), and the distances of neighboring Zn1···Na1 (3.1874(11), 3.3375(12), and 3.5780(12) Å) are obviously shorter than the sum atomic radius of Na and Zn (3.76 Å). On the other hand, each [ZnO4] tetrahedron also shares three corners with three neighboring [CP2O3] tetrahedrons into a 63 Zn−O−P layer, which also consists of 6MRs. Thus, the structure can be described as 1,2-ethylenediphosphonate groups connecting the Zn−O−P layers and Na+ cations to form an interesting 3D framework.

elements.content: Crystal Structure of [K 2 Zn 2 (HO 3 P(CH 2 ) 2 PO 3 H)(O 3 P(CH 2 ) 2 PO 3 )] (2). The asymmetric unit of 2 includes two K(I) atoms, two Zn(II) atoms, and four [CPO3] groups (Figure ). Both K(I) atoms are seven-coordinated and connect six 1,2-ethylenediphosphonate groups. The K1−O and K2−O distances lie in the range of 2.687(4)−3.138(4) and 2.704(4)−2.987(4) Å, respectively. Each Zn(II) atom contacts four neighboring K(I) atoms through three corners and an edge. Different from that in 1, the 1,2-ethylenediphosphonate group exhibits two coordination modes. However, whether the 1,2-ethylenediphosphonate group is in the μ10:η2:η1:η2:η2:η1:η2 or μ10:η1:η2:η3:η1:η2:η3 coordination mode, it always bonds four Zn(II) atoms and six K(I) atoms. [ZnO4] tetrahedrons share corners with [CPO3] tetrahedrons to form a wavelike Zn−O−P layer, which is composed of 8MRs (Figures and S7, SI). This is different from that in 1. Then the 1,2-ethylenediphosphonate groups connect the Zn−O−P layers and K+ cations into an interesting 3D framework.

elements.content: Crystal Structure of [(NH 4 )(H 3 N(CH 2 ) 2 NH 3 ) 0.5 Zn 3 (O 3 P(CH 2 ) 2 PO 3 ) 2 ] (3). The structure of 3 is more complicated and composed of an unprecedented 3D Zn−O−P framework with 8MR and 12MR channels along the b axis, which are occupied by NH4 + and H3N(CH2)2NH3 2+ cations, respectively (Figure ). In metal diphosphonates M−O−P chains or layers are usually interrupted by organic units of diphosphonate groups to further form a 3D architecture. Therefore, such a 3D Zn−O−P framework has not been reported in the realm of metal diphosphonates. The 1,2-ethylenediphosphonate group is in a μ6:η1:η1:η1:η1:η1:η1-coordinated environment and bonds six Zn(II) atoms (Figure S8, SI), which is the same as for that in [(C5H14N2)Zn4(HO3PCH2CH2PO3H)(O3PCH2CH2PO3)2]. On one hand, three −O−P−O− groups bridge neighboring Zn1a and Zn2 to form a double metal building unit consisting of three 4MRs. On the other hand, Zn3b contacts neighboring Zn3c through two −O−P−O− groups into another type of double metal building unit, which only consists of one 4MR. Both double metal building units contact alternatively through another −O−P−O− bridge to form a Zn−O−P chain, which is composed of 8MRs and 4MRs.

elements.content: Crystal Structure of [(NH 4 ) 2 Zn 3 (O 3 P(CH 2 ) 3 PO 3 ) 2 ] (4). The structure of 4 is a 3D framework consisting of 4 × 82 Zn−O−P layers, infinite Zn−O−P chains, and ethylene groups (Figures and S9, SI). Such a 3D framework is obviously different from the pillared structures of zinc propylenediphosphonates. Similar to the 1,2-ethylenediphosphonate group in 3, the 1,3-propylenediphosphonate group is also in a μ6:η1:η1:η1:η1:η1:η1-coordinated environment and bonds six Zn(II) atoms. In the chain, two [Zn2O4] and two [CP2O3] tetrahedrons share four corners in a 4MR. The Zn2(II) atom is a node to link neighboring 4MRs into a Zn−O−P chain. In the Zn−O−P layer, each [Zn1O4] tetrahedron shares three corners with three neighboring [CP1O3] tetrahedrons, while each [CP1O3] also contacts three neighboring [Zn1O4] tetrahedrons via three corners. Thus, [Zn1O4] and [CP1O3] tetrahedrons share corners with each other in a 4 × 82 Zn−O−P layer, which consists of 4MRs and 8MRs. The Zn−O−P chain and the Zn−O−P layer interact with each other through corner-sharing (O6) between [Zn1O4] and [CP2O3], resulting in a more complicated 3D Zn−O−P framework. Like that in 3, the 3D Zn−O−P framework also possesses 12MR and 8MR channels, which are occupied by propylene groups and NH4 + cations, respectively.

elements.content: Crystal Structure of [(H 3 N(CH 2 ) 4 NH 3 ) 0.5 Zn(O 3 P(CH 2 ) 3 PO 3 H)] (5). As shown in Figures and S10 (SI), propylene groups combine infinite Zn−O−P entangling chains into a pillarlike layer. [H3N(CH2)4NH3]2+ cations fill in the void space between layers and interrupt the pillar layers to form a 3D framework. Unlike that in 4, the 1,3-propylenediphosphonate group in 5 is in a μ4:η1:η1:η1:η1-coordinated mode and only bonds four Zn(II) atoms. In the Zn−O−P chain, each [ZnO4] tetrahedron shares four corners with four neighboring [CPO3] tetrahedrons. In other words, two [ZnO4] tetrahedrons are bridged by two [CPO3] tetrahedrons through four corners into a 4MR. The [ZnO4] tetrahedron acts as a node to link the 4MRs into the Zn−O−P chain. The interactions between the organic−inorganic layers are through strong hydrogen bonding of O6−H1···O3C (d O6 ··· O3C = 2.503(2) Å). In addition, [H3N(CH2)4NH3]2+ cations contact neighboring hybrid layers also with hydrogen bonds, such as N1−H8···O2c (d N1 ··· O2c = 2.872(3) Å), N1−H9···O5 (d N1 ··· O5 = 3.088(3) Å), and N1−H10···O3 [d N1 ··· O3 = 2.761(3) Å].

elements.content: Crystal Structure of [KZn(O 3 P(CH 2 ) 4 PO 3 H)] (6). The asymmetric unit of 6 consists of one K(I) atom, one Zn(II) atom, and one O3P(CH2)4PO3H group (Figure ). The 1,4-butylenediphosphonate group is in a μ10:η2:η1:η2:η2:η3:η2 coordination mode. As a result, each 1,4-butylenediphosphonate group bonds four Zn(II) atoms and six K(I) atoms, which is the same for the 1,2-ethylenediphosphonate group in 2. The K(I) atom is eight-coordinated with eight surrounding oxygen atoms from six different 1,4-butylenediphosphonate groups. Because the O1d and O2d atoms are from the same 1,4-butylenediphosphonate group, the bond angle O1d−K1−O2d is only 51.89(7)°. This phenomenon also occurs on the O4 and O5 oxygen atoms, so the bond angle O4−K1−O5 is only 48.53(6)°. Each Zn1(II) center contacts three neighboring K1(I) atoms through two edges (O3 and O5b, O6 and O5b) and a corner (O4a). As a result, the distance Zn1···K1 (3.3584(9) and 3.4581(9) Å) is obviously shorter than the sum atomic radius of Zn and K (4.30 Å).

elements.content: Each [ZnO4] tetrahedron shares three corners with three neighboring [CP2O3] tetrahedrons, and each [CP2O3] tetrahedron also contacts three neighboring [ZnO4] tetrahedrons through three corner-sharings. Thus, interaction results in a ladderlike Zn−O−P chain, which is different from that in 5 (Figures and S11, SI). The chains are pillared by 1,4-butylenediphosphonate groups along the a axis into a novel hybrid layer, and the hybrid layers are further linked by K(1) atoms in a 3D pillared framework.

elements.content: Crystal Structure of [KZn(HO 3 P(CH 2 ) 4 PO 3 H)(Cl)] (7). The asymmetric unit of 7 consists of one K(I) atom, one Zn(II) atom, one Cl- anion, and one HO3P(CH2)4PO3H group (Figure ). The 1,4-butylenediphosphonate group is in a μ7:η3:η1:η2:η1:η2 coordination mode and links three Zn(II) atoms and four K(I) atoms. Different from those in 2 and 6, the K(I) atom is in a [KO6Cl3] nine-coordinated environment. The K−O and K−Cl bond lengths lie in the range of 2.7804(16)−3.2300(15) and 3.1605(7)−3.4406(5) Å, respectively. Each [ZnO3Cl] tetrahedron contacts four K(I) atoms around itself through one face (O1, O6, Cl1) and three corners (O1, Cl1, and Cl1). The distance Zn···K is 3.4406(5) Å, which is also obviously shorter than the sum atomic radius of Zn and K (4.30 Å). On one hand, each Cl- anion is in a μ4 coordination mode and bonds three K(I) atoms and one Zn(II) atom. On the other hand, K(I) atoms are linked by a Cl- anion in an interesting K−Cl lamella (Figure S12, SI). Along the c axis, the [ZnO3Cl] tetrahedron and [CP2O3] tetrahedron share a corner (O5) alternatively in a Zn−O−P single chain, which is different from those in 5 and 6, and the chains are combined by 1,4-butylenediphosphonate groups into a pillared double layer. Therefore, the structure can be described as a K−Cl lamella insert into the void space between pillared double layers to form an intriguing 3D sandwichlike framework (Figure ).

Different from those in 2 and 6, the K(I) atom is in a [KO6Cl3] nine-coordinated environment. The K-O and K-Cl bond lengths lie in the range of 2.7804(16)-3.2300(15) and 3.1605(7)-3.4406(5) Å, respectively. Each [ZnO3Cl] tetrahedron contacts four K(I) atoms around itself through one face (O1, O6, Cl1) and three corners (O1, Cl1, and Cl1). The distance Zn⋅⋅⋅K is 3.4406(5) Å, which is also obviously shorter than the sum atomic radius of Zn and K (4.30 Å). On one hand, each Cl- anion is in a μ4 coordination mode and bonds three K(I) atoms and one Zn(II) atom. On the other hand, K(I) atoms are linked by a Cl- anion in an interesting K-Cl lamella (Figure S12, SI). Along the c axis, the [ZnO3Cl] tetrahedron and [CP2O3] tetrahedron share a corner (O5) alternatively in a Zn-O-P single chain, which is different from those in 5 and 6, and the chains are combined by 1,4-butylenediphosphonate groups into a pillared double layer. Therefore, the structure can be described as a K-Cl lamella insert into the void space between pillared double layers to form an intriguing 3D sandwichlike framework (Figure ).

elements.content: Crystal Structure of [NH 4 Zn(O 3 P(CH 2 ) 4 PO 3 H)] (8). X-ray single-crystal diffraction reveals that ladderlike Zn−O−P infinite chains, [CP1O3] tetrahedrons, and butylene groups constitute a 2D pillarlike layer in 8 (Figures and S13, SI). The 1,4-butylenediphosphonate group is in a μ4:η1:η1:η1:η1 coordination mode and links four Zn(II), which is the same as for the 1,3-propylenediphosphonate group in 5. Two [ZnO4] and two [CP2O3] tetrahedrons share four corners in a 4MR. Neighboring 4MRs connect each other alternatively through two corners in a ladderlike Zn−O−P chain, which is the same as that in 6 and different from those in 5 and 7. In addition, in the hybrid layer the role of the [CP1O3] tetrahedron and butylene group is to combine the Zn−O−P chains via a corner with a [ZnO4] tetrahedron and a C−P bond, respectively. The pillarlike layers are bridged by NH4 + in 3D frameworks. Each NH4 + contacts neighboring layers with hydrogen bonds, including N1−H1···O5c (d N1 ··· O5c = 3.006(3) Å), N1−H2···O2 (d N1 ··· O2 = 2.775(2) Å), N1−H3···O2c (d N1 ··· O2c = 3.108(3) Å), and N1−H4···O5d (d N1 ··· O5 = 2.952(2) Å). Those hydrogen bonds may play an important role in stabilizing the structure.

elements.content: Structural Comparison. An obvious difference is present among four zinc ethylenediphosphonates (1 − 3 and [(C5H14N2)Zn4(HO3PCH2CH2PO3H)(O3PCH2CH2PO3)2] with various cations, including Na+, K+, C5H14N2 2+, NH4 +, and H3N(CH2)2NH3 2+. 1 and 2 and [(C5H14N2)Zn4(HO3PCH2CH2PO3H)(O3PCH2CH2PO3)2] contain Zn−O−P layers, which are separated by −CH2CH2− groups, while 3 possesses Zn−O−P 3D open-framework encapsulating −CH2CH2− groups. Zinc propylenediphosphonates with [H3N(CH2)4NH3]2+ (for 5), C5H14N2 2+ (for [(C5H14N2)Zn2(O3PCH2CH2CH2PO3H)2], and NH4 + (for 4) have a Zn−O−P chain, a layer, and a 3D open framework, respectively. Furthermore, Na+ and C5H14N2 2+ are captured on the Zn−O−P layers in the 3D zinc butylenediphosphonate frameworks, while K+ (for 6) and NH4 + (for 8) lie between zinc butylenediphosphonate hybrid layers. From the above results, we conclude that zinc alkylenediphosphonates can exhibit structural diversity by the incorporation of various cations.

Zinc propylenediphosphonates with [H3N(CH2)4NH3]2+ (for 5), C5H14N2 2+ (for [(C5H14N2)Zn2(O3PCH2CH2CH2PO3H)2], and NH4 + (for 4) have a Zn-O-P chain, a layer, and a 3D open framework, respectively. Furthermore, Na+ and C5H14N2 2+ are captured on the Zn-O-P layers in the 3D zinc butylenediphosphonate frameworks, while K+ (for 6) and NH4 + (for 8) lie between zinc butylenediphosphonate hybrid layers. From the above results, we conclude that zinc alkylenediphosphonates can exhibit structural diversity by the incorporation of various cations.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric Analysis. As shown in Figure S14 (SI), there are two small weight loss stages between 70 and 450 °C with 3.0% total weight losses for 1. After that, a sharp weight loss stage appears, indicating the collapse of the framework of 1. TGA curves of 2 − 8 reveal that there are small weight losses up to 480, 220, 420, 330, 420, 240, and 290 °C, respectively. The TGA curve of 5 also indicates a weight loss stage appears between 330 and 440 °C with 13.6% weight loss, corresponding to the removal of 1,4-butylenediamino (calcd 14.2%). Furthermore, the thermal stability of 7 is also studied with powder XRD. After a polycrystalline sample of 7 was annealed at 250 °C for 2 h under an air atmosphere, the powder XRD patterns were in good agreement with those simulated from X-ray single-crystal data (Figure S4), which unambiguously indicates the retention the framework of 7 at that temperature.

elements.content: Luminescent Properties. 1, 3, 5, and 7 do not display any photoluminescence, while it is intriguing that 1b could emit bright purple-blue luminescence (λem max = 420 nm) under excitation at 340 nm (Figure ). The full width at half-maximum (fwhm) is about 87 nm, and the lifetime (λex = 345 nm, monitored at 421 nm) is only 1.04(3) ns (Figure S16, SI). The emission of 1b may originate from the commercial fluorescent whitener (disodium 4,4‘-bis(2-sulfonatostyryl)biphenyl) (λem max = 452 nm, excited at 410 nm), which is adsorbed onto the 1b surface during the reaction. Interestingly, the peak band of 1b exhibits an about 32 nm blue shift compared to that of disodium 4,4‘-bis(2-sulfonatostyryl)biphenyl, resulting in the transformation of luminescent color from blue-green to purple-blue.

elements.content: When excited at 270 nm at room temperature, 4 emits a luminescence in the ultraviolet region with a narrow band profile (Figure ). The peak band appears at 319 nm with a shoulder at 310 nm. The fwhm is only about 35 nm. The lifetime (λex = 270 nm, monitored at 320 nm) is 5.3(2) ns (Figure S16). In contrast, when excited at 280 nm at room temperature, 8 gives off a blue-green luminescence with a broad band profile. The peak band appears at 434 nm. The fwhm is about 215 nm, which is almost 6 times larger than that of 4. The lifetime (λex = 397 nm, monitored at 466 nm) is 55(3) ns, which is 10 times longer than that of 4.

elements.content: Suitable single crystals of eight new zinc diphosphonates have been successfully obtained under mixed solvothermal conditions. X-ray single-crystal diffraction reveals that their structures were induced by the lengths of the alkylenediphosphonic acids (H2O3P(CH2) n PO3H2, n = 2−4) together with the cations, including Na+, K+, NH4 +, H3N(CH2)2NH3 2+, and H3N(CH2)4NH3 2+, resulting in Zn−O−P chains, layers, and 3D frameworks. 1, 2, and 6 exhibit interesting 3D Na/K−Zn frameworks. The complicated structures of 3 and 4 possess novel 3D Zn−O−P frameworks consisting of 8MR and 12MR channels, while the structures of 5 and 8 are 2D pillarlike layers, which are separated by H3N(CH2)4NH3 2+ and NH4 +, respectively. It is interesting that in 7 K−Cl lamellae insert into the void space between pillared double layers to form an intriguing 3D sandwichlike framework. In addition, 1b, 4, and 8 exhibit attracting photoluminescence. In future work we will continue to use the mix-solvothermal method to synthesize unique metal phosphonates with special properties.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Suitable single crystals of eight new zinc diphosphonates have been successfully obtained under mixed solvothermal conditions. X-ray single-crystal diffraction reveals that their structures were induced by the lengths of the alkylenediphosphonic acids (H2O3P(CH2) n PO3H2, n = 2-4) together with the cations, including Na+, K+, NH4 +, H3N(CH2)2NH3 2+, and H3N(CH2)4NH3 2+, resulting in Zn-O-P chains, layers, and 3D frameworks. 1, 2, and 6 exhibit interesting 3D Na/K-Zn frameworks. The complicated structures of 3 and 4 possess novel 3D Zn-O-P frameworks consisting of 8MR and 12MR channels, while the structures of 5 and 8 are 2D pillarlike layers, which are separated by H3N(CH2)4NH3 2+ and NH4 +, respectively. It is interesting that in 7 K-Cl lamellae insert into the void space between pillared double layers to form an intriguing 3D sandwichlike framework. In addition, 1b, 4, and 8 exhibit attracting photoluminescence. In future work we will continue to use the mix-solvothermal method to synthesize unique metal phosphonates with special properties.

Synthesis of [NaZn(O 3 P(CH 2 ) 2 PO 3 H)] (1). A mixture of Zn(CH3COO)2·2H2O (0.1069 g, 0.4870 mmol), H2O3P(CH2)2PO3H2 (0.0583 g, 0.307 mmol), NaCl (1.0254 g, 17.546 mmol), n-butyric acid (8.0 mL, 86 mmol), and H2O (2.0 mL, 111 mmol) was heated at 180 °C for 164 h. After the mixture was allowed to cool slowly to ambient temperature, colorless needle-shaped crystals were obtained. The final pH of the solution was 1.05. The crystals were filtered, washed with distilled water, and dried at ambient temperature. The pattern of powder XRD was in agreement with that simulated from single-crystal X-ray data, which indicated a homogeneous phase. The yield was about 12% (0.0101 g) based on H2O3P(CH2)2PO3H2. Anal. Calcd for C2H5O6P2NaZn (1):  C, 8.72; H, 1.83. Found:  C, 8.81; H, 2.23. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1):  3462m, 2960w (νC - H), 2924m (νC - H), 2911w (νC - H), 2866w (νC - H), 2401w, 2054w, 1618m, 1417m (δC - H), 1201s (νP  O), 1157s (νP - O), 1109vs (νP - O), 1076vs (νP - O), 1051s (νP - O), 1005vs (νP - O), 924s, 885w, 804m, 758m, 717m, 563m, 528m, 490m, 471m. In addition, 1 can also be obtained with commercial fluorescent whitener (disodium 4,4‘-bis(2-sulfonatostyryl)biphenyl) in the initial mixture as follows. A mixture of Zn(CH3COO)2·2H2O (0.1115 g, 0.5080 mmol), H2O3P(CH2)2PO3H2 (0.0577 g, 0.304 mmol), NaCl (1.1827 g, 20.238 mmol), disodium 4,4‘-bis(2-sulfonatostyryl)biphenyl (0.2798 g, 0.4974 mmol), n-butyric acid (8.0 mL, 86 mmol), and H2O (2.0 mL, 111 mmol) was heated at 160 °C for 144 h. After the mixture was allowed to cool slowly to ambient temperature, blue needle-shaped crystals (denoted as 1b) were obtained. The final pH of the solution was 2.12. The crystals were filtered, washed with distilled water, and dried at ambient temperature. After the blue needle-shaped crystals were ground into a white powder, the powder XRD pattern was essentially in agreement with that simulated from X-ray single-crystal data. The IR spectrum of 1b is also in accord with that of 1.

Crystal Structure of [(NH 4 ) 2 Zn 3 (O 3 P(CH 2 ) 3 PO 3 ) 2 ] (4). The structure of 4 is a 3D framework consisting of 4 × 82 Zn−O−P layers, infinite Zn−O−P chains, and ethylene groups (Figures and S9, SI). Such a 3D framework is obviously different from the pillared structures of zinc propylenediphosphonates. Similar to the 1,2-ethylenediphosphonate group in 3, the 1,3-propylenediphosphonate group is also in a μ6:η1:η1:η1:η1:η1:η1-coordinated environment and bonds six Zn(II) atoms. In the chain, two [Zn2O4] and two [CP2O3] tetrahedrons share four corners in a 4MR. The Zn2(II) atom is a node to link neighboring 4MRs into a Zn−O−P chain. In the Zn−O−P layer, each [Zn1O4] tetrahedron shares three corners with three neighboring [CP1O3] tetrahedrons, while each [CP1O3] also contacts three neighboring [Zn1O4] tetrahedrons via three corners. Thus, [Zn1O4] and [CP1O3] tetrahedrons share corners with each other in a 4 × 82 Zn−O−P layer, which consists of 4MRs and 8MRs. The Zn−O−P chain and the Zn−O−P layer interact with each other through corner-sharing (O6) between [Zn1O4] and [CP2O3], resulting in a more complicated 3D Zn−O−P framework. Like that in 3, the 3D Zn−O−P framework also possesses 12MR and 8MR channels, which are occupied by propylene groups and NH4 + cations, respectively.

Thermogravimetric Analysis. As shown in Figure S14 (SI), there are two small weight loss stages between 70 and 450 °C with 3.0% total weight losses for 1. After that, a sharp weight loss stage appears, indicating the collapse of the framework of 1. TGA curves of 2 − 8 reveal that there are small weight losses up to 480, 220, 420, 330, 420, 240, and 290 °C, respectively. The TGA curve of 5 also indicates a weight loss stage appears between 330 and 440 °C with 13.6% weight loss, corresponding to the removal of 1,4-butylenediamino (calcd 14.2%). Furthermore, the thermal stability of 7 is also studied with powder XRD. After a polycrystalline sample of 7 was annealed at 250 °C for 2 h under an air atmosphere, the powder XRD patterns were in good agreement with those simulated from X-ray single-crystal data (Figure S4), which unambiguously indicates the retention the framework of 7 at that temperature.

Luminescent Properties. 1, 3, 5, and 7 do not display any photoluminescence, while it is intriguing that 1b could emit bright purple-blue luminescence (λem max = 420 nm) under excitation at 340 nm (Figure ). The full width at half-maximum (fwhm) is about 87 nm, and the lifetime (λex = 345 nm, monitored at 421 nm) is only 1.04(3) ns (Figure S16, SI). The emission of 1b may originate from the commercial fluorescent whitener (disodium 4,4‘-bis(2-sulfonatostyryl)biphenyl) (λem max = 452 nm, excited at 410 nm), which is adsorbed onto the 1b surface during the reaction. Interestingly, the peak band of 1b exhibits an about 32 nm blue shift compared to that of disodium 4,4‘-bis(2-sulfonatostyryl)biphenyl, resulting in the transformation of luminescent color from blue-green to purple-blue.

When excited at 270 nm at room temperature, 4 emits a luminescence in the ultraviolet region with a narrow band profile (Figure ). The peak band appears at 319 nm with a shoulder at 310 nm. The fwhm is only about 35 nm. The lifetime (λex = 270 nm, monitored at 320 nm) is 5.3(2) ns (Figure S16). In contrast, when excited at 280 nm at room temperature, 8 gives off a blue-green luminescence with a broad band profile. The peak band appears at 434 nm. The fwhm is about 215 nm, which is almost 6 times larger than that of 4. The lifetime (λex = 397 nm, monitored at 466 nm) is 55(3) ns, which is 10 times longer than that of 4.
